image.altText: A crowd of people stand on the street outside an Optus store

items.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says the company has not identifed the root cause of the outage affecting millions of Australians, while there is "no indication" it has been caused by a cyber attack. Follow live.

title.children: Optus announces some services are being restored, but warns it may take a few hours

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier, we reported that Optus mobiles could still call emergency services. But now Optus says some customers can't. We are aware of some mobile phones are having issues connecting to 000. If Optus customers need to call emergency services, we suggest finding a family member or neighbour with an alternative device.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus says some mobiles can't call triple-0

children.content: Earlier, we reported that Optus mobiles could still call emergency services.
But now Optus says some customers can't.
We are aware of some mobile phones are having issues connecting to 000.
If Optus customers need to call emergency services, we suggest finding a family member or neighbour with an alternative device.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm seeing some comments from people who are back online. But a bunch of you aren't. The latest post on the Optus Help X account (the social media platform formerly known as Twitter) says "some" services are fixed. But it might take a while. We don't have a concrete timeframe, but here's what the company says: "This may take a few hours for all services to recover, and different services may restore at different sites over that time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus: Restoring full service 'may take a few hours'

children.content: I'm seeing some comments from people who are back online.
But a bunch of you aren't.
The latest post on the Optus Help X account (the social media platform formerly known as Twitter) says "some" services are fixed.
But it might take a while.
We don't have a concrete timeframe, but here's what the company says:
"This may take a few hours for all services to recover, and different services may restore at different sites over that time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's the latest from Optus: Some services across fixed and mobile are now gradually being restored. This may take a few hours for all services to recover, and different services may restore at different sites over that time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus 'gradually' restoring services

children.content: Here's the latest from Optus:
Some services across fixed and mobile are now gradually being restored.
This may take a few hours for all services to recover, and different services may restore at different sites over that time.

image.altText: A hand holding a Cochlear implant.

items.synopsis: The Queensland government will pay out $5,000 to $50,000 in compensation to patients, many children, after a sweeping review of the treatment of audiology patients at Townsville University Hospital saw two staff immediately stood down.

image.altText: Palestinian family reacts following Israeli airstrike

items.synopsis: At least 500 more people, most of them foreign nationals, cross into Egypt after the Rafah border crossing re-opens, while an Israeli government spokesperson tells the ABC the country will have to exercise "ultimate security control" over the Gaza Strip. Follow live.

title.children: DFAT confirms three Australians among new Rafah crossing evacuations, Israel wants 'ultimate security control' over Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A total of 28 Australians have now managed to cross from Gaza to Egypt with the help of goverment officials, with most of them already back in Australia, a Department of Foreign Affairs spokesperson has told the ABC. A family of three Australian citizens crossed the border to Egypt through Rafah on November 7, the ABC has confirmed. Departures out of Gaza depend on "a range of factors", the spokesperson said, with a challenging situation on the ground changing rapidly. "The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is assisting 76 individuals in Gaza, including Australians and their families, who have requested our help to depart", the DFAT said. "Australia is doing what we can to support those Australians and their families still in Gaza, including providing the best available information and options for their safety, and communicating through all available channels." The spokesperson said Australia was supporting international efforts to keep the Rafah border crossing open for humanitarian purposes and for civilians to pass through. Australians in need of emergency consular assistance should contact the Australian Government's 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another three Australians cross from Gaza to Egypt, bringing the total to 28, DFAT confirms

children.content: A total of 28 Australians have now managed to cross from Gaza to Egypt with the help of goverment officials, with most of them already back in Australia, a Department of Foreign Affairs spokesperson has told the ABC.
A family of three Australian citizens crossed the border to Egypt through Rafah on November 7, the ABC has confirmed.
Departures out of Gaza depend on "a range of factors", the spokesperson said, with a challenging situation on the ground changing rapidly.
"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is assisting 76 individuals in Gaza, including Australians and their families, who have requested our help to depart", the DFAT said.

"Australia is doing what we can to support those Australians and their families still in Gaza, including providing the best available information and options for their safety, and communicating through all available channels."
The spokesperson said Australia was supporting international efforts to keep the Rafah border crossing open for humanitarian purposes and for civilians to pass through.
Australians in need of emergency consular assistance should contact the Australian Government's 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on
(from overseas) or
(from within Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends. Yesterday Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu raised the prospect of Israel taking control of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated. "Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't," Eylon Levy, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told Patricia Karvelas on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words. He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza Strip would have to be demilitarised. The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said. When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated: "When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time. "We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years." Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel wants to exercise 'ultimate security control' over Gaza after war, government spokesperson says

featuredLink.title: What happens to Gaza when the conflict ends? - ABC listen

children.content: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends.
Yesterday Israeli PM
Benjamin Netanyahu
raised the prospect of Israel taking control
of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated.
"Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't,"
Eylon Levy
, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told
Patricia Karvelas
on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words.
He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza Strip would have to be demilitarised.
The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said.
When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated:
"When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time.
"We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years."
Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Even before the October 7 Hamas attacks, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was in hot water. Anger at him has been boiling for months over his unwavering push to change Israel's judiciary, coupled with a cost-of-living crisis. "Since his re-election to the top job at the end of 2022, Bibi, as he's known to most people here, has created a deep rift inside Israeli society that's gone to heart of the future of this country," Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn writes. "Even in times of political crisis, one thing usually holds Israel together. Security. But this month has been different. "Many people who already believed Bibi had divided the country now hold him responsible for the most shocking breach of Israeli defences in half a century." Read the full analysis by Allyson Horn below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dissatisfaction towards Netanyahu intensifies in Israel

featuredLink.title: 'The real problem is the guy who's our leader': Israelis are furious with PM Benjamin Netanyahu

children.content: Even before the October 7 Hamas attacks,

Anger at him has been boiling for months over his unwavering push to change Israel's judiciary, coupled with a cost-of-living crisis.
"Since his re-election to the top job at the end of 2022, Bibi, as he's known to most people here, has created a deep rift inside Israeli society that's gone to heart of the future of this country,"
Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn
writes.
"Even in times of political crisis, one thing usually holds Israel together. Security. But this month has been different.
"Many people who already believed Bibi had divided the country now hold him responsible for the most shocking breach of Israeli defences in half a century."
Read the full analysis by Allyson Horn below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac has announced it will dump PwC as its external auditor and put the work up for tender. The major bank told the ASX on Wednesday morning it had commenced a search for its external audit services and that PwC, the current provider, "has not been invited to participate in the tender". "The decision to tender the audit reflects best practice for audit firm rotation," it said in the statement. PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) was appointed Westpac's external auditor by shareholders in 2002 and individuals who were partners of PwC or its antecedent firms have been the external auditors since 1968, the bank said. "Due to their tenure as the Group's external auditor, PwC has not been invited to participate in the tender," the statement said. Over the past five years, PwC has been the biggest recipient of audit and non-audit work from the major banks, reaping about $700 million since the 2017 financial year. The move to exclude PwC from re-tendering for its audit services comes ahead of Westpac's annual general meeting on December 14.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Westpac to dump PwC as its auditor

children.content: Westpac has announced it will dump PwC as its external auditor and put the work up for tender.
The major bank told the ASX on Wednesday morning it had commenced a search for its external audit services and that PwC, the current provider, "has not been invited to participate in the tender".
"The decision to tender the audit reflects best practice for audit firm rotation," it said in the statement.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) was appointed Westpac's external auditor by shareholders in 2002 and individuals who were partners of PwC or its antecedent firms have been the external auditors since 1968, the bank said.
"Due to their tenure as the Group's external auditor, PwC has not been invited to participate in the tender," the statement said.
Over the past five years, PwC has been the biggest recipient of audit and non-audit work from the major banks, reaping about $700 million since the 2017 financial year.
The move to exclude PwC from re-tendering for its audit services comes ahead of Westpac's annual general meeting on December 14.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: S & P Global Market Intelligence has revised its forecast for US real GDP growth down for 2023 from 2.5 per cent to 2.4 per cent, and for 2024 from 1.6 per cent to 1.4 per cent. It says that despite an easing of financial conditions after the US Federal Reserve's recent meeting, it raised its near-term projections of both term yields and the US dollar, which thereby encouraged the downward revision in its forecast of growth for 2024. But the agency still expects more rate hikes from the Fed. "Following the recent Fed meeting, investors shifted strongly to the view that this tightening cycle is over," the agency said in a statement. "Nevertheless, S & P Global Market Intelligence still expects the Fed to raise its policy rate in December to a peak range of 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent, with a reversal of policy in June. "However, our call is highly dependent on incoming data — especially for inflation — and so remains under constant review. "We continue to expect that a period of below-trend growth, with a rise in the unemployment rate to 4.5 per cent to 5 per cent, will be required to bring inflation down to 2 per cent within a time frame acceptable to the Fed."'
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: S&P Global revises outlook for US growth, forecasts more Fed rate hikes

children.content: S
P Global Market Intelligence has revised its forecast for US real GDP growth down for 2023 from 2.5 per cent to 2.4 per cent, and for 2024 from 1.6 per cent to 1.4 per cent.

It says that despite an easing of financial conditions after the US Federal Reserve's recent meeting, it raised its near-term projections of both term yields and the US dollar, which thereby encouraged the downward revision in its forecast of growth for 2024.
But the agency still expects more rate hikes from the Fed.
"Following the recent Fed meeting, investors shifted strongly to the view that this tightening cycle is over," the agency said in a statement.
"Nevertheless, S
P Global Market Intelligence still expects the Fed to raise its policy rate in December to a peak range of 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent, with a reversal of policy in June.

props.alt: A view of the Federal Reserve

children.content: There could be more rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve
(AFP: Brendan Smialowski)
"However, our call is highly dependent on incoming data — especially for inflation — and so remains under constant review.

"We continue to expect that a period of below-trend growth, with a rise in the unemployment rate to 4.5 per cent to 5 per cent, will be required to bring inflation down to 2 per cent within a time frame acceptable to the Fed."'
